content.text: Georgia is a country at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Western Asia, nestled between the Black Sea, Russia, Turkey, Armenia, and Azerbaijan. Covering about 69,700 km², it is famed for its dramatic Caucasus mountains and lush lowlands. The capital, Tbilisi, is home to over a third of its roughly 3.7 million people. Renowned as one of the world’s oldest wine regions, Georgia’s modern culture reflects millennia of history and hospitality.

items: Language: Georgian (ქართული), plus Russian and widely understood English in urban areas
Visa/Entry: Visa-free for many countries (often up to 1 year) – check official sources
Emergency: Dial 112 for police, fire, or medical

description.text: From the humid Black Sea coast in the west to the continental interiors of Tbilisi and Kakheti, and up to alpine heights in the Caucasus, Georgia’s climate zones vary dramatically:

items: Western Georgia (Black Sea): Subtropical, wet winters and warm summers.
Eastern Georgia (Tbilisi/Kakheti): Hot, dry summers and cooler winters.
Mountain Regions: Alpine conditions; heavy snow in winter, cool summers.

content.text: Best time to visit: April–June and September–October for mild weather, blossoming spring, or autumn foliage.

Georgians are world-famous for hospitality—“Every guest is a gift from God.” Greetings often include a handshake and direct eye contact; acquaintances may exchange a light kiss on the cheek. Use simple phrases: gamarjoba (გამარჯობა) for “hello” and madloba (მადლობა) for “thank you.” Dress modestly when entering homes or churches, and remove your shoes in private dwellings. Dining customs revolve around the supra, a grand feast led by a toastmaster (tamada). Wait for the tamada’s toast before drinking, hold your glass with both hands, and maintain eye contact. It’s polite to accept at least a small taste of any food or drink offered. Tipping around 10% is customary in restaurants.

items: Georgia is generally safe; watch for petty theft in crowded areas.
Avoid travel to Abkhazia and South Ossetia (conflict zones).
Health care is best in major cities; travel insurance is recommended.
Tap water is usually safe in cities; bottled water is widely available.
ATMs and credit cards (Visa/Mastercard) are common in urban centers.

content.text: In cities, use licensed taxis or ride-hail apps (e.g., Bolt). Tbilisi’s metro and bus network are affordable (~1 GEL). For intercity travel, marshrutkas (minibuses) and trains connect major towns. Renting a car offers flexibility but be cautious on mountain roads. Internet & SIM: Free Wi-Fi is widespread; for full coverage buy a local SIM (Magti, Silknet/Geocell) at airports or kiosks. Tourist SIM packages include data and minutes.
Georgia appeals to a range of visitors:

items: Adventure seekers: Hiking, mountaineering, skiing in the Caucasus.
Wine & food lovers: Traditional feasts and 8,000-year-old qvevri wines in Kakheti.
History buffs: UNESCO sites like Mtskheta, Gelati Monastery, and Svaneti tower villages.
Beachgoers: Black Sea resorts near Batumi in summer.
